_exec_summary.SummaryText:
in OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program.  We are committed to continually improving our safety, health, and environmental programs to ensure a safe and healthy environment for our employees, contractors, and the public.
  
We conduct ongoing training and preplanning for emergencies.  We steward progress of process safety and RMP prevention program elements as key performance indicators.  A variety of changes are being implemented as a result of learnings from the BP Texas City incident investigation--including upgrades of facility siting and relief devices.  Security is being upgraded by extending the site's perimeter to reduce potential exposures to critical infrastructures. Over the past year, we have implemented changes to our energy isolation, working at heights, work permitting, and operating/maintenance procedure processes to continuously improve their overall effectiveness.

We plan to maintain this high level of commitment and improvement to our environmental, health and safety programs consistent with our past EHS performance by continually improving through sharing best practices.

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

ExxonMobil Oil Corporation
ExxonMobil Beaumont Refinery (BMRF)
Beaumont, Texas  77701
Risk Management Plan (RMP)
Executive Summary

June 17, 2009
 
1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies

The ExxonMobil Beaumont Refinery maintains a policy to be a good business partner and a safe and conscientious community member who operates the facility in full compliance with all applicable laws and regulations. 

The Beaumont Refinery has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This is evidenced by:

o	Our history of support and commitment to the community;
o	Our high environmental standards; and 
o	Our recognition and certification as a STAR facility in the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health AdministrationÂ¿s (OSHA) Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) since 1996.  In May 2009, we were awarded our 4th OSHA STAR.  We are listed by OSHA as a "Star Among Stars."

The Beaumont Refinery utilizes a management system framework called Operations Integrity Management System (OIMS) to effectively establish safety, health, and environmental expectations and manage operating integrity risks.  OIMS addresses all aspect of the business, including security measures to prevent unnecessary on-site human exposure and to minimize the potential for any offsite exposure.  The 11 OIMS elements are: 

1. Management, Leadership, Commitment and Accountability
2. Risk Assessment and Management
3. Facilities Design and Construction
4. Information/Documentation
5. Personnel and Training
6. Operations and Maintenance
7. Management of Change
8. Third-Party Services
9. Incident Investigation and Analysis
10. Community Awareness and Emergency Preparedness
11. Operations Integrity Assessment and Improvement

By effectively managing the procedures, technology, and personnel interfaces that produce excellence in our operations, we minimize risks and thus effectively manage and minimize the impact of process related incidents.

2.  Description of the Stationary

Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Beaumont Refinery operates a variety of processes to produce petroleum products (e.g. jet fuel, diesel fuel, kerosene, gasoline, LPG, lubricant base stocks and specialty wax) from raw crude oil.  These processes contain regulated flammable substances and flammable mixtures, which may include:  hydrogen, methane, ethane, ethylene, propane, propylene, isobutane, butane, butylene, pentane, and isopentane.  Hydrogen sulfide occurs naturally in  crude oil and is present in some refinery processes.  In addition, the Refinery uses chlorine for water treatment and ammonia for refrigeration and air emissions control.  Since the 2004 RMP, the Refinery has shut down and deinventoried the Duosol and Ketone 1 units, eliminating 215,000 lbs of propane and 100,000 lbs of anhydorus ammonia inventory.

3.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program

To ensure that our Risk Management Program is effectively implemented and managed, the Refinery Manager has assigned the role of RMP Coordinator to a staff member with the necessary training, experience, and resources to coordinate implementation of our Risk Management Program.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with the authority delegated directly from the Refinery Manager, has the responsibility for the development and implementation of our risk management programs.

The Beaumont Refinery has developed programs to comply with the industryÂ¿s most stringent environmental, health, and safety standards.  The Beaumont Refinery is the largest oil refinery in the U.S. that is STAR certified.  Facilities in the STAR program are required to demonstrate exemplary safety performance and agree to work cooperatively with OSHA to serve as an example for the industry.  OSHA audits these facilities for compliance every 3 to 5 years in order to maintain certification.

Much effort has also been devoted to environmental programs such as waste reduction and emissions minimization.  The Beaumont Refinery volunt

arily participated in the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 33/50 Toxic Release Inventory Reduction Program and exceeded the reduction goals set forth in the program.  The Refinery participates in the Texas Clean Industry Recycling program and has developed a partnership with the neighboring Charlton-Pollard residential area to improve the residents' quality of life and strengthen our environmental programs.  These efforts highlight only a few of the programs underway within the Refinery to protect our environment.

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our OIMS elements address each of the essential features of successful accident prevention programs including:

- Employee participation	OIMS Element 1, 2, and 5
- Process safety information	OIMS Element 4
- Process hazard analysis	OIMS Element 2
- Incident investigation	OIMS Element 9
- Operating procedures	OIMS Element 6
- Training			OIMS Element 5
- Mechanical integrity	OIMS Element 6
- Management of change 	OIMS Element 7
- Pre-startup safety review	OIMS Element 7
- Hot work permit		OIMS Element 6
- Contractor safety		OIMS Element 8
- Emergency Preparedness	OIMS Element 10
- Compliance audits		OIMS Element 6 and 11

Our RMP uses these individual elements to prevent accidental chemical releases.  

In addition to our industry-leading management programs, we have designed state-of-the-art systems and equipment to control, prevent, detect, and mitigate potential accidental releases.  An important tool for managing changes, for example, is our Safe Operations Committee (SOC), which is responsible for reviewing all process changes. 

We employ extensive mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance programs to ensure the integrity of our equipment and safety systems.  Our mechanical integrity program uses equipment surveillance and preventive maintenance activities to identify equipment that may be in need of repair or replacement, before failure occu

rs.  This program also specifies the repairs (or parts replacement) needed to maintain equipment in acceptable operating condition.

We train our employees to safely perform their assigned tasks.  Our training program includes new employee training as well as periodic refresher training and training updates when major process or equipment changes are made. Training is also provided for special topics, such as the management of change (MOC) system.   As part of our training, we include provisions for ensuring that employees understand the covered material, including written tests and field demonstrations.

4. Five Year Accident History

The Beaumont Refinery has had no accidents that met the criteria for the Five-Year Accident History.  

5. Emergency Response Program Information

The Beaumont Refinery Emergency Response Program is outlined and managed under OIMS Element 10.  This system serves as the final line of defense against, and the mechanism for response to, accidental releases and other emergencies.  While the other elements of the Risk Management and Process Safety Management Programs are focused on the prevention of incidents and releases of highly hazardous material, the Emergency Response Plans serve as the guidelines for responding to accidental releases and other emergencies if and when they do occur.

The Beaumont Refinery has an extensive emergency response organization, including resources from the ExxonMobil Beaumont Chemical Plant, which utilizes state-of-the-art equipment.  Emergency drills and exercises are conducted frequently and coordinated with the City of Beaumont's Fire Department, the SheriffÂ¿s Department, various governmental agencies (TCEQ, Coast Guard, LEPC) local hospitals, and the news media.  Emergency drills, self-inspections, and insurance inspection results provide a continual improvement process to keep plans current and equipment prepared.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Beaumont Refinery Complex is a STAR facility
